layman:
**Admission diagnoses:**  
- Broken right hip (neck of the femur)  
- History of Alzheimer’s disease  
- Low thyroid hormone (hypothyroidism)

**Discharge diagnoses:**  
- Broken right hip (neck of the femur)  
- History of Alzheimer’s disease  
- Low thyroid hormone (hypothyroidism)  
- After having a partial hip replacement (hemiarthroplasty)

**Procedure performed:**  
- Partial hip replacement on the right hip

**Consultations:**  
- Medicine team to manage multiple health problems, including Alzheimer’s

**Hospital course:**  
The patient was admitted on August 6, 2007 after falling and breaking his right hip. He was taken to the Orthopedics department and had a consultation with Medicine. He went to the operating room on the same day, with consent signed by his durable power of attorney. He had a right hip hemiarthroplasty and recovered without complications. He continued to be confused and had dementia, which is his usual baseline because of Alzheimer’s. After surgery his white blood cell count rose briefly but then returned to normal. Urine and blood cultures were negative. The patient was stable and was sent home to Heartland.

**Condition on discharge:**  
Stable

**Discharge instructions:**  
- Transfer to ABC for rehabilitation and ongoing care.  
- Follow a diabetic diet.  
- Walk as you can, but keep the hip protected (posterior hip precautions).  
- Rehabilitation potential is fair.  
- You will need help from nursing, social work, physical/occupational therapy, and a nutritionist.  
- Resume your regular medications, blood‑clot prevention (DVT prophylaxis), aspirin, and compression stockings.  
- Schedule a follow‑up with Dr. X in one to two weeks; call 123‑4567 to make an appointment.
